document.text: The National Park Service has prepared a land protection plan for Appomattox Court House National Historical Park. The plan was prepared in response to the Department of the Interiors policy requirement that any agency using the land and water conservation fund, prepare a land protection plan for any area containing non-federal lands within its boundaries. Appomattox Court House National Historical Park is such an area, and the plan was prepared and is now available for public review and comment. The plan basically concerns itself with one tract of 22.19 acres along Route 24 in the north-western part of the park. The National Park Service currently hold a scenic easement of this tract, but because of ambiguities in the easement, some types of development - would be .-possible. The plan is recommending that either these development rights be acquired or that the lands be acquired in fee. The plan is available for review at park headquarters any weekday from 830 a.m. - 500 p.m. For additional informaiton, please call 352-8987.

document.text: Over 240,000 visits were re corded at Appomattox Court House National Historical Park during 1971. Approximately 85.000 persons visited Lees Headquarters, Grants Head quarters and the Confederate Cemetery. Approximately 155.000 persons toured the re stored village compared to 148.000 in 1970 making 1971 the second biggest year for vil lage visitation. Last year was the first year that visitors were counted at Lees Headquarters, Grants Headquarters and the Confed erate Cemetery. In the past, said Park Superintendent Alec Gould, we had assumed that persons visiting these areas would also enter the village, but surveys showed that this was not the case. A visitor, for ex ample, who hiked the trail at Lees Headquarters and didnot go to the village was counted last year. Another family who visited both Lees Headquarters and the village was counted only once. Road counter and per iodic surveys to determine re duction factors for persons vis iting more than one area are used in the visitor count sys tem. Few northern ers, however, settled permanently in Appomattox after the war. The end of the U.S, military occupation of Appomattox County signalled a return to  normal pattern of life fra most county residents. The Reconstruction years, writes John Hammond Moore, do not seem to have had any special impact upon Appomattox and its citizens. Gurney, Superintendent of Appomattox Court House National Historical Park, announced today that the Guillaume painting, The Surrender cf General Lee to General has been re- Grant, April 9, 1865, movedfrom the Park Museum for repairs. It was traced to the Univer sity of Michigan and located in the Clements Library there. A pro posal to purchase the painting and present it to the Park won wide public approval. Individuals and or ganizations in Lynchburg and Ap pomattox raiesd the necessary funds, 1,250, and the canvas was trans ferred to the Park Museum on July 1, 1954. At that time, Mr. Waiter Nitkie- wicz, painting restorer with the Mu seum Branch, National Park Service, examined the canvas and reported that it would require reinforcing. During the past winter months the Park Superintendent noticed in creased checking on the surface of the canvas, Mr. Nitkiewicz was call ed from Washington to report on the painting. Acting on his advice, and under his supervision, the paint ing was removed from the frame and crated preparatory to shipment for repairs. The National Park Service Mu seum Branch has assured Mr. Gur ney that every effort will be made to complete these repairs as quick ly as possible, in order to place the painting back on display.

New comfort stations, in the re constructed slave quarters at the Old Tavern, will be completed this month and the Tavern itself is being given a handsome reconstruction job. It will be used for National Park Serv ice offices, and will house the enlarg ed museum. New museum exhibits are expect ed to arrive the week of April 18, to add to the many historical relics now on display. The museum has been located in the old Ferguson residence, where there hag not been room for adequate display. A continuous effort goes to ob tain museum items for Appomattox. Many of the items secured during the past year have been sent to Park Service shops to be prepared for ex hibit, and some of these items are now ready for public view. The mu seum in the restored Tavern is ex pected to be a mecca for tourists. Mr. Gurney announced today that 5,800 is now available for buildirg an utility house east of the Peers House.
